The  Project  will  introduce  a  computerized,  double–entry,  cash 
basis  public  accounting  system  (PAS)  with  a  central  ledger.  The 
Project  will  also  reassign  and  consolidate  responsibility  for  the 
overall  government  accounting  function  and  for  check  issuance 
with the Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT). 
 
Strengthening  of  the  PAS  will  enhance  good  governance  by 
improving  efficiency,  enhancing  accountability  and  transparency, 
and  contributing  to  more  effective  public  sector  management,  as 
well  as  to  the  development  of  effective  fiscal  operations  and 
macroeconomic  policy.  The  quality  of  governance  in  public 
finance  management  is  critical  for  ensuring  expenditures  for 
programs  targeting,  reducing  poverty,  preventing  corruption  and 
fraud  and  reducing  the  vulnerability  of  the  Maldives  to  external 
shocks. 
 
The objectives are to (i) promote improved budget practices, thus 
enhancing  financial  management  as  well  as  the  development  of 
effective  fiscal  operations  and  macroeconomic  policymaking; 
(ii) establish  accurate,  reliable,  and  timely  financial  reporting  to 
meet  international  accounting  standards  by  eliminating  laborious 
manual financial reporting systems, promoting accountability, and 
providing  appropriate  financial  information  to  the  Government  for 
economic decision making; and (iii) conduct more comprehensive 
and  updated  control  over  public  funds,  and  help  develop  a  cash 
management  strategy 
to  rationalize  cash  movements  and 
holdings, especially for the atolls and islands. 
 
The Project components include (i) restructuring the organization 
of ministries and departments (by establishing finance sections in 
ministries,  assigning  accounting  and  internal  audit  function  to 
MOFT,  and  establishing  accounting  units  in  the  atolls  and 
islands); 
introducing  core 
government  funds;  chart  of  accounts;  a  ledger  structure;  and  a 
voucher  system  for  ministries,  atolls,  and  islands;  and  preparing 
annual  financial  statements;  (iii)  streamlining  the  function  of  the 
Maldives  Monetary  Authority  (MMA)  for  the  PAS  by  reassigning 
the banking function to MMA, and establishing one public account; 
and (iv) supporting human resource development and training.

Introducing  the  new  PAS  will  entail  the  following  main  benefits: 
(i) improving the quality, timeliness, and integrity of the accounting 
system  will  enhance  transparency  and  accountability,  and  thus 
strengthen  governance;  (ii)  reliable  and  timely  information  on  the 
financial  position  of  the  Government  will  enable  the  Government 
to  conduct  more  competent  fiscal  policy  and  macroeconomic 
management to reduce the vulnerability to external shocks due to 
the  high  dependency  of  the  Maldivian  economy  on  imports  and 
limited  income  derived  from  tourism  and  fishing;  (iii) reliable 
information on the fiscal status of the country will enhance lenders 
and investor confidence in the country; (iv) external reports will be 
prepared to meet internationally accepted accounting standards to 
enable  better  assessment  by  international  rating  agencies;  and 
(v) significant  reductions  in  idle  cash  holdings  of  ministries  and 
atolls  will  lead  to  better  financial  returns  on  public  funds  through 
improvements in fiscal discipline and cash management.

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 

1. 
to the Republic of the Maldives for the Strengthening of the Public Accounting System Project.  
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

2. 
High dependence of the Maldivian economy on imports, and limited income derived from 
tourism  and  fishing  exacerbates  its  vulnerability  to  external  shocks.  The  effects  of  external 
shocks are quickly transmitted to the poor.  Hence, despite the significant economic and social 
progress  achieved,  the  incidence  of  poverty  is  still  substantial,  particularly  in  the  highly 
dispersed, small, and sparsely populated islands. This poses major structural challenges for the 
country as articulated in the Government’s Sixth National Development Plan (2001–2005). The 
Government's  public  expenditures  account  for  more  than  40%  of  the  gross  domestic  product. 
Thus, public sector intervention is a powerful tool for economic and social development. 
 
The Government's growth and poverty reduction strategy focuses on strengthening the 
3. 
macroeconomic  framework  and  good  governance  in  the  public  sector,  supporting  human 
development,  and  improving  the  policy  environment  for  the  public  and  private  sectors. 
Establishing  a  modern  public  administration  system,  governed  by  a  comprehensive  and 
transparent  set  of  laws,  and  an  impartial  and  competent  judiciary  is  prioritized  in  the 
Government’s  development  agenda,  while  efficient  control  and  utilization  of  public  money  is 
underscored as a means to attaining the maximum benefits from the development program. 

The  operational  strategy  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for  the  Maldives 
4. 
supports poverty reduction through a combination of pro-poor growth, social development, and 
good  governance  initiatives.  For  pro-poor  growth,  ADB’s  assistance  is  fostering  regional 
development.  To  raise  the  level  of  social  development,  ADB’s  focus  is  on  assisting 
postsecondary education and skills development. To support good governance, ADB is focusing 
on  developing  improved  information  access  and  public  sector  connectivity,  and  improving  the 
effectiveness  of  public  sector  management.  Introduction  of  a  new  public  accounting  system 
(PAS)  will  enhance  good  governance  by  improving  efficiency  and  control  of  public  money, 
enhancing  accountability  and  transparency,  and  contributing  more  effectively  to  public  sector 
management  as  well  as  the  development  of  effective  fiscal  operations  and  macroeconomic 
policy.  Once  funds  that  are  dispersed  throughout  the  system  are  clearly  identified  and 
consolidated,  they  could  then  be  utilized  for  programs  targeting  poverty  reduction  and 
preventing  corruption  and  fraud, 1  which  mostly  affect  the  poor.  Moreover,  the  quality  of 
governance  in  public  finance  management  is  critical  in  reducing  the  vulnerabilities  of  the 
Maldives to external shocks. 
      
Since  1994,  the  Government  has  been  collaborating  with  aid  agencies  to  develop  a 
5. 
more  efficient  public  finance  system.  More  recently,  the  public  expenditure  and  public 
accounting  systems  were  enunciated  as  issues  for  immediate  attention  in  the  Sixth  National 
Development  Plan.  Under  a  World  Bank  initiative,  ADB  and  the  International  Monetary  Fund

single public account and check issuance unit will tighten control over spending beyond budget appropriation. The 
Internal  Audit  Bureau,  being  established  under  the  Project,  will  monitor  legitimacy  of  public  financial  operations,

(IMF)  are  preparing  the  first  public  expenditure  review  for  the  Maldives.  The  objectives  of  the 
review  are  to  assess  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  the  Government’s  spending  program 
and its institutional aspects, particularly in light of poverty reduction, and to recommend a reform 
agenda for improving public sector spending. Preliminary findings of the review underscore the 
need for a new PAS, as proposed by this Project. 
 
6. 
The  public  accounting  and  auditing  system  needs  to  be  streamlined  to  enable  public 
money to be managed in an efficient and accountable manner. ADB has been working with the 
Government  for  the  past  5  years  as  its  lead  partner  in  achieving  this  goal.  ADB  provided 
technical assistance (TA)2 to the Government from August 1997 to December 1998 to conduct 
an  assessment  of  the  existing  PAS  and  to  identify  its  major  limitations,  inadequacies,  and 
weaknesses.  This  was  followed  by  TA3 to  identify  the  legal,  institutional,  and  human  resource 
requirements for introducing a new PAS.  
 
7. 
In  April  2001,  after  reviewing  the  findings  and  recommendations  of  these  studies,  the 
Government  decided  to  adopt  the  design  and  the  supporting  reform  strategies  for  introducing 
the new PAS.4  During the Country Strategy and Program Mission in May 2001, the Government 
asked  ADB  to  provide  a  project  preparatory  TA5 for  the  proposed  Project.  The  TA  vetted  the 
details of how a new PAS could interface with and update the existing accounting system with 
as  little  disruption  to  the  economy  as  possible,  through  a  critical  review  of  proposed  PAS 
models,  system  requirements,  and  capabilities  in  the  Maldives.  The  findings  of  the  TA  team 
were  then  discussed  in  detail  with  the  Technical  Advisory  Team  and  the  Ministerial  Level 
Advisory Group. The feedback received was included in the final TA report. Building on the TA 
recommendations and findings, a fact-finding mission6 was undertaken from 7 to 18 April 2002 
for the Project. This report is based on the understandings reached with the Government during 
fact-finding. The project framework is detailed in Appendix 1. 
 
A. 

Performance Indicators, and Analysis 

8. 
The  current  PAS  is  rudimentary  and  does  not  achieve  the  overall  objectives  and 
consistent performance criteria required for PAS. These objectives and criteria include provision 
of  accurate  and  adequate  information  in  a  timely  manner  on  the  financial  position,  budgetary 
commitments  and operation results of the funds (surplus or deficit positions) monitored by the 
accounting  groups  of  ministries  and  atolls,7 in  accordance  with  generally  accepted  accounting 
principles; compliance with finance-related constitutional, statutory, and legal requirements and 
contractual  provisions  of  the  country;  and  streamlined  financial  reporting  to  enable  budgetary 
and accounting functions to be complementary and to effectively integrate elements of financial 
management and audits.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Capacity Constraints 

 
Public sector staff involved with the accounting function work at a relatively rudimentary 
9. 
level  in  line  with  the  requirements  of  a  manual,  line-budget  oriented  accounting  system.  To 
ensure  adequate  implementation  of  the  new  PAS,  the  skills  mix  will  have  to  be  substantially 
upgraded  not  only  to  implement  the  new  accounting  practices,  but  also  for  financial 
management,  preparation  and  analyses  of  financial  statements,  and  their  use  as  inputs  into 
macroeconomic policymaking. Other external funding agencies have not assisted in this area as 
the  absorptive  capacity  of  the  Government  is  limited.  While  the  Project  will  provide  focused 
capacity building in phases to the relevant staff vis-à-vis workshops and on-the-job training, the 
pace  of  the  process  will  largely  be  determined  by  the  existing  and  absorptive  capacity  of  the 
staff being trained. 
 
10. 
A  new  PAS  would  not  have  been  effective  without  the  necessary  legal  foundation. 
Hence, under the capacity-building TA (footnote 3), three key bills for the public finance act, the 
amendments of the Audit Act, and the public enterprise act were drafted and are being reviewed 
by the Maldivian legislative authorities for adoption. The bills aim to define the legal framework 
within  which  the  transparent  and  efficient  implementation  of  the  new  PAS  can  be  enforced, 
ultimately  ascertaining  an  alignment  of  the  newly  introduced  rules  with  practices.  Many  of  the 
concepts, some of the terminology included in the bills are novel. Hence, a training workshop on 
these new bills, in conjunction with the Public Service Division of the President's Office, as part 
of  the  Seminar  on  Financial  Management,  was  held  in  June  2002,  for  a  group  of  senior 
government officials and financial managers of public sector organizations.  
 

2. 

Scope for Improvement of the Existing Public Accounting System   

 
The  existing  PAS,  which  was  introduced  more  than  three  decades  ago,  is  subject  to  a 
11. 
number of constraints. The financial legislative framework is not comprehensive. Currently, the 
country  has  an  outline  legal  framework  for  regulating  control  of  public  finances  including  the 
PAS.  The  framework  components  are  the  Constitution  of  the  Republic  of  the  Maldives  1997,8 
and in operational terms, the Financial Regulations.9 Under the current PAS, no annual financial 
statements  regarding  the  Government’s  financial  position  and  status  are  reported  to  the 
People’s Majlis,10 and no audited financial statements are prepared. The annual accounts and 
information  on  Government  finances  are  presently  included  in  budget  papers 11  and  the 
Government  Budget  in  Statistics  Handbook.12 In  fact,  no  policies  identify  the  ownership  and 
responsibility  for  the  accounting  function,  and  provide  for  a  data  entry  system.  Only  a  limited

3. 

Life of the Project  

 
12. 
The Project is to be implemented over 3 years. While this may appear to be a relatively 
tight schedule, the pace of implementation is important. The Maldivian economy urgently needs 
a new PAS. Support for the Project is strong throughout the Government, and the momentum 
must  not  be  lost  during  implementation.  The  dependence  on  information  technology  and 
computers,  while  facilitating  a  less  labor-intensive  and  more  user-friendly  introduction  to  the 
system,  necessitates  a  reasonable  pace  of  transition  from  the  existing  to  the  new  PAS.  The 
specialized accounting software and hardware to be used must still be at par with the rest of the 
world by the time the new PAS is operational. Designed carefully over the last 2 years in close 
consultation  with  the  Government,  the  current  timetable  is  realistically  achievable  from  both 
technical and absorptive capacity perspectives at this time. However, the Project will be closely 
monitored  by  ADB  and  the  Government;  three  monitoring  missions  and  two  comprehensive 
reviews  of  the  Project  are  scheduled.  If  during  implementation,  a  longer  implementation 
schedule appears to be needed, then both ADB and the Government will explore the availability 
of additional funding or TA from ADB and other donors.

will relieve the central bank, Maldives Monetary Authority (MMA), from performing the dual role 
of a government banker and administering government accounting functions. This new system 
will enable proper segregation of functions and duties by transferring the accounting functions of 
Government to the Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT) while the banking functions remain 
with MMA. 
 
The  new  system  will  also  enable  government  ministries  and  departments  to  do  away

with a number of accounting records currently being kept in the existing system without proper 
monitoring and coordination by MOFT. Analysis of the project preparatory technical assistance

years  or  so,  the  savings  will  increase  substantially.  Existing  staff  can  be  redeployed  in  other 
areas of importance or retrained, or the staff complements could be reduced by natural attrition, 
thereby making the government operations more efficient and cost effective.  Implementation of 
the Project as part of the reform process could require additional human resources, which may 
be met in part by surplus staff from the finance sections.

Better and Timely Decision Making 

 

4. 
The main aim of the existing system is to control the budget through the treasury general 
account  maintained  at  MMA.  More  than  60%  of  the  monthly  reports  that  are  required  to  be 
submitted  to  MOFT  by  the  various  government-spending  units  arrive  significantly  late.  Such 
information is critical for good and timely decision making and required by a number of users. 
 
5. 
By  2004,  a  national  computer  network  will  likely  be  established  under  an  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  financed  project.  This  network  together  with  the  proposed  PAS  will 
pave  way  for  the  new  PAS  to  be  connected  to  the  national  network,  enabling  on-line  enquiry 
and printing of various financial reports by the government-spending units. This connectivity will 
bring improvements to the timeliness and quality of decisions made.

The centralized PAS supported by the legislative amendments will provide much needed

transparency and accountability to the management of public finance.

Human Resource Development 

7. 
Qualified  financial  management  capacity  is  lacking  in  MOFT.  Hence,  development  of 
qualified personnel to manage the proposed accounting system will be critical to the success of 
the  Project.  Good  cash  or  treasury  management  and  analytical  skills  will  be  essential 
ingredients to successfully manage the PAS and achieve the expected outcomes.

Improved Monitoring and Reporting Mechanisms 

 
 
8. 
Currently, the Government operates over 1,600 bank accounts at MMA. These accounts 
are  not  adequately  controlled.  Although  the  existing  budget  system  does  record  cash 
disbursements  made  against  the  allocated  budget  for  a  particular  item,  it  does  not  record  the 
commitments made against those funds at the time of ordering and registered commitments or 
not.  

 

The  establishment  of  the  treasury  division  under  the  Project  will  become  an  effective 
9. 
means by which government can save substantial amounts of public money. The existing audit 
system lacks the resources and access to timely information.  Figures provided by the Maldives 
Audit  Office  indicate  an  annual  average  loss  of  Rf2  million  due  to  lack  of  proper  internal 
controls.  These  losses  have  occurred  through  fraud  and  inefficiency.  Availability  of  timely 
information will be enhanced in the new system and a more effective internal and external audit 
function  would  be  carried  out,  which  will  be  likely  to  act  as  a  deterrent  for  parties  engaging  in 
misappropriation and embezzlement of public funds. 
  
10. 
Another  major  reporting  deficiency  of  the  existing  PAS  is  the  inability  of  the  system  to 
produce  a  set  of  audited  financial  statements  of  the  Government.    At  the  end  of  each  year,  a 
consolidated  statement  of  actual  expenditure  against  budgeted  expenditure  is  prepared,  but 
does  not  conform  to  international  accounting  standards,  nor  does  the  auditor  general  express 
an opinion on these financial statements of the Government. 
 
11. 
The  Project  will  specifically  address  these  particular  issues,  and  the  proposed  system 
should  be  able  to  generate  annual  reports  such  as  statements  of:  (i)  assets  and  liabilities; 
(ii) consolidated  revenue  fund;  (iii)  general  loan  fund  and  capital  works;  (iv)  trust  fund; 
(v) revolving fund; (vi) contingency fund; and (vii) other customized reports.  
 
Such  reports,  if  prepared  and  independently  audited  will  facilitate  the  process  of  The

markets at much more favorable terms. Though this benefit could be substantial in the long run,
